column5: assessment method
column7: justification

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it automatically assigns a persistent identifier to a research artefact.
A system is assessed yes (y) if, in addition to a possible unique identifier local to the system, it also supports the generation of a DOI for a research artefact.
column7: Does not generate DOIs

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it allows the import of idenfiers of the research artefact, external to itself.
column7: Can import from DOI and ORCID.

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides a unique identifier for research artefacts that is dereferenceable to the artefact's location in the system.
column7: URLs to artefact in eprints are based on internal IDs

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it enables search over the metadata of the research artefact.
A system is assessed yes (y) if it enables search over the content of the research artefact.
column7: Can search content and provide customised search methods.

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides advanced search features and, if so, justify by listing the features.
column7: The documentation is uncleare about advanced search

column5: A system is assessed as providing language support (y) if its interface is available in more than one language.
column7: Translations are possible but not provided by default.

column5: A system is assessed as providing protocols and APIs (y) if it makes available at least one protocol and/or API for access to research artefacts.
column7: Eprints provide a complete API to customise and access the system locally. There is a REST API, but the documentation is not very clear about it (or was not found).

column5: A system is assesssed yes (y) if it offers a convenient mechanism to perform a long term preservation beyond a simple database backup.
column7: Includes METS and DIDL exportplugins

column5: A system is assed high if the uptime is >= 99,9%, it is assessed medium if the uptime is between 99,9% and 99% and low if it is below 99% .
column7: Unknown - could not find reports for known instances of Eprints

column5: A system is assessed open, if it makes research artefacts public by default. It is assessed as closed if it is primary designed for closed repositories. It is assessed on-request if it offers an on-request feature.
column7: The system is built to enable flexible accress control.

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it employs a standardised and established format for providing the metadata.
column7: own metadata format internally

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the provision of data in common and standard file formats.
column7: Based on the requirements for full-text indexing, Eprints appears to support PDF, Microsoft Word and HTML formats for publications

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it assigns a persistent identifier (e.g. a stable URL) to the research artefacts.
column7: see above

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it allows to customize, extend and limit the metadata schema/format.
column7: It is possible to setup the system with custom fields

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the creation and publication of semantic links between different metadata and/or research artefacts.
column7: No information found in documentation

column3: Import and upload of metadata and content
column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the import and upload of metadata and data via multiple means, e.g. a web frontend or a standard API. It is assessed partially (p) if it only supports the provision via a web interface.
column7: Can import from specific XML file, but can also be connected to others through API

column3: Export and download of metadata and content
column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it supports the export and download of metadata and data via multiple means, e.g. a web frontend or a standard API. It is assessed partially (p) if it only supports the download via a web interface.
column7: Can  export  to  many  metadata  formats, including dublin core, variants of RDF (using BIBO), ReNotes, citaions, etc. Although documenation has not been found about it.

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) it it supports the creation and maintenance of a customised submission process, including fine-grain access control and role assignment.
column7: Can be setup by administrator

column5: A system is assessed yes (y) if it provides a built-in mechanism to make the metadata and data in other repositories (running the same system) available.
column7: Not found in documentation. Import plugins can be developped, but don't seem to be provided by default.

column5: A system is assessed high (h) if it provides a highly usable and easy-to-understand mechanism to select a fitting licence for an artefact. It is assessed limited (l), if it at least provides a customizable controlled list of licences.
column7: Instances don't appear to have this field, and the documentation does not include information about licences

column5: A system is assessed high (h) if it provides an easy-to-understand and human-readable description of the terms of use. It is assessed limited (l), if it at least provides a link to the applied licence.
column7: Instances don't appear to have this field, and the documentation does not include information about licences

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it allows to access the actual content in a structured and machine-readable manner, if the data format supports it, for example, if a user can access the content of a CSV via an API.
column7: PDF content is available for publications.

column5: A system is assessed high (h) if the documentation and support are of high quality and reachability.
column7: Wiki-based documentation, which is rich but incomplete and not very accessible to non-technical users

column5: A system is assessed according to this metrics based on usability testing carried out.
column7: No report found

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes mechanisms to notify users through mobile apps, email, or other mechanisms.
column7: Can be configured to send alerts

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a way to customise and manage the publication/deposit workflow.
column7: Custom deposite process can be setup by administrator

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes ways to visualise the content of publications or datasets, at least for some formats.
column7: No visualisation tool mentioned in documentation.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes mechanisms to analyse the data in deposited research artefacts, including basic statistical analysis or more advanced methods.
column7: No analysis tool mentioned in documentation.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables the publisher or administrator to change the aspect of pages on the system to reflect institutional affiliation.
column7: Instance can be themed and branded by the deploying institution.

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes ways for users to create, name, and publish arbitrary sets of research artefacts.
column7: Not found in documentation

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides pages for individual researchers, including at least the research artefacts they have authored/published.
column7: Only includes list of publications

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it gives the ability to users to provide simple positive feedback ("like") on research artefacts.
column7: Not found in documentation or instances

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables users to comment on individual research artefacts.
column7: Not found in documentation or instances

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides ways to share research artefacts with other users, on the system or other platforms (e.g. social media).
column7: social media button exist in instances, but might be part of custom theme as not documented

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it enables users to follow, and receive updates from, other users, research artefacts, collections, institutions, etc.
column7: Not found in documentation or instances

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes discussion forums for users and/or for communication with/from the administrators.
column7: Not found in documentation or instances

column5: For a proprietary, closed system, the assessement should be "closed" (c). For an open system, assessement is based on the frequency of activities in the development community (daily/weekly updates: high, monthly/quaterly updates: medium, less: low)
column7: Regular commits on github

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes an authentication mechanism for users.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a review functionality during submission by data stewards or other permitted organizational users.
column7: As part of the custom deposit process

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes a functionality for writing reviews on specific research artefacts.
column7: Not found in documentation or instances

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (s) if it records usage statistics and (a) if it provides advanced research indicators like h-Index or AltMetrics.
column7: Indicators of downloads and views

column5: Date at which the first available artefact was deposited on the platform.
A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if the underlying system is open source.
column7: The system is open source

column5: A system is assessed as having high uptake (h) if it is used by a thousands of active users each month.
column7: unknown

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes automated backups in a constant time interval.
column7: Not found in documentation

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a function to get all data about one user.
column7: No specific process available

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides a function to delete all data about one user.
column7: No specific process available

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it allows the user to opt-in, agreeing to single personal data management processes individually.
column7: Not found in documentation

column3: Portable and secure data exchange format
column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it provides all personal data in an open standard format (e.g. HTML, TXT, PDF).
column7: Not found in documentation

column5: A system is assessed as possessing the feature (y) if it includes security tests for personal data.
column7: Not found in documentation
